awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Institutionalizing Standards in Clinical Genome Editing
awd_abstract_narration:
This project investigates the process by which regulatory guidelines and standards of practice are developed: How do best practices and standard operating protocols become institutionalized into formal policies, guidelines and norms?  It does so for the technology of genome editing, specifically for the case of the DNA editing tool CRISPR and the technological breakthrough it represents. To address social and ethical implications raised by these technologies, scientists have convened open conference forums, but academic and industry scientists largely make decisions about the direction of research, the standards of efficacy and measurement, and the safety of clinical protocols behind closed doors. Findings will contribute to the training of scientists and decision-making concerning science.

Data concerning determination of guidelines and standards of practice will be gathered through interviews, participant observation, and archival research at the Center for Biologics Evaluation and Research (CBER) of the U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA) and at the National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST) in the Department of Commerce. The project's methodology builds on the conventions of laboratory studies by using the extended-case method of ethnography, which relies on comparative data and multi-site participant observation to trace decentralized processes. By describing the process by which regulatory guidelines are produced by stakeholders at strategic sites of institutionalization, this project contributes to the sociology of science and technology, organizations and political sociology.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project sought to understand the social impact of new genetic technologies that allow scientists to modify human DNA. These genome editing technologies have become powerful laboratory tools and are starting to be used in clinical trials. Sociologists have previously shown how political, economic and cultural contexts can shape how new technologies are produced and used. These dynamics can lead to the reproduction of health inequities, as new clinical options cannot be equitably accessed.

            The project drew from participant observation, interviews and archival sources to describe how standards of safety, efficacy, and ethical guidelines for clinical genome editing are being established. Funds from the National Science Foundation supported the collection and analysis of these data. By describing the process by which regulatory guidelines are produced by stakeholders at strategic sites of institutionalization, this project contributes to past work in the sociology of science and technology, organizations and political sociology. Contrasting with some research that suggests that civil society groups, such as patient advocacy organizations and non-profits can have an impact on the direction of research, in the case of genome editing, industry and academic interests override the concerns of disability justice advocates, patients and ethicists. The project found that while scientists attempt to involve members of the general public through conferences, engagement efforts do not lead to the development of ethical guidelines or standards. Instead, the sites where decisions are made about what genome editing will look like, how it is evaluated and what it is for are held behind closed doors in meetings of scientists, industry stakeholders and regulators.

The data from the project support a theory of institutionalization, where new technologies become normalized through interactions between scientists and different kinds of stakeholders, such as regulators, ethicists, and journalists. At these interaction points scientists shape how a technology is talked about, define what the ethical and technical issues are and help smooth over any controversies that may arise. This theory of institutionalization is useful for describing the politics of knowledge surrounding other technologies, such as artificial intelligence, autonomous vehicles, and nanotechnology.

These findings are being disseminated through peer reviewed publications, publicly accessible blogs and were presented at academic conferences. Findings were presented in the 2020 meetings of the American Sociological Association, the Society for the Advancement of Socioeconomics and the Society for the Social Studies of Science.
